doc.after: After the Central Powers launched Operation Faustschlag on the Eastern Front, the new Soviet Government of Russia signed the Treaty of Brest-Litovsk with Germany on 3 March 1918.[14] This treaty ended the war between Russia and the Central powers and annexed 1,300,000 square miles (3,400,000Â km2) of territory and 62 million people.[15] This loss equated to one third of the Russian population, 25 per cent of their territory, around a third of the country's arable land, three-quarters of its coal and iron, a third of its factories (totalling 54 per cent of the nation's industrial capacity), and a quarter of its railroads.[15][16]
